block.p: Hemispheric Leaders Agree on Free-Trade Talks President Clinton, 21 other presidents and 12 prime ministers in the Western Hemisphere signed a declaration in Chile calling for talks in September on creating the world's largest free-trade zone, one that would span the Americas, with the goal of signing an agreement by 2005.

China Frees Dissident Leader China freed Wang Dan, a leader of the 1989 Tiananmen democracy movement, and sent him into exile in the United States, in a move the Chinese Government clearly hoped would score points with the Clinton Administration in advance of the President's visit to China.

China Frees Dissident Leader China freed Wang Dan, a leader of the 1989 Tiananmen democracy movement, and sent him into exile in the United States, in a move the Chinese Government clearly hoped would score points with the Clinton Administration in advance of the President's visit to China.
American officials welcomed Mr. Wang's release, but said it was only a small step toward full rights.

After a nonstop flight from Beijing, Mr. Wang landed in Detroit and was driven directly to Henry Ford Hospital, where he began undergoing a variety of tests. The hospital's chief medical officer said Mr. Wang was in stable and good condition.

Bloody West Bank Dispute A small group of unarmed Palestinian shepherds in the West Bank confronted three Jewish settlers on a rocky field that both sides claim as theirs, and in the ensuing fight one of the settlers was shot dead, another was injured and one of the Arabs was severely wounded.
Apology From Austrian Cardinal The head of the Roman Catholic Church in Austria apologized for the behavior of his predecessor, who is accused of having molested young seminarians.

Colombian Rights Lawyer Killed A top human rights lawyer in Colombia was shot and killed, the authorities said. Eduardo Umana Mendoza, a crusading defender of Colombia's underclass whose clients included trade unionists, jailed guerrillas and families of the country's many missing people, was killed in his office in Bogota.

Sudan Appeals For Famine Aid The Sudanese Government appealed to humanitarian organizations for food and medicine for parts of southern Sudan that are facing famine. Two days earlier, the United Nations' food operation accused the Government of hampering efforts to feed 350,000 people in the south. The Government apparently has been concerned that aid supplies were falling to insurgents.

A Record Backlog Delays Naturalization More than two million immigrants throughout the country are waiting to become citizens of the United States, the largest backlog of naturalization applications since the Federal Government began keeping those records at the turn of the century. The backlog means that for those people in the pipeline -- legal residents of the United States who, for the most part, have already waited five years for the right to apply -- the waiting time for citizenship is up to 18 months, immigration officials said. Before the backlog started increasing in 1996, the normal waiting time was 6 months.

Universities Are Criticized The acclaimed research universities of the United States are shortchanging their undergraduate students, particularly freshmen, according to an unusually candid report from the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, one of the nation's leading education-policy organizations. The report said that universities had consigned undergraduates to classes taught by graduate assistants and failed to provide students with ''a coherent body of knowledge'' by the time they graduated.

Arrest Reveals a Secret Life Palm Beach society has been rattled by the arrest late last week of William Stephen Martin, who was taken into custody on 19-year-old warrants from Massachusetts charging him with the 1979 abduction of his two daughters, Lisa, at top, and Rachel, who were 2 and 4 years old, respectively, at the time. The police said the girls believed that their mother was dead. The authorities also said that wasn't the only lie that Mr. Martin had told; they said his name is not William Stephen Martin.

Zenith Plans More Layoffs Zenith said it would lay off 388 workers at its suburban Chicago television picture tube plant as it struggles to compete against cheaper Japanese television sets. The layoffs add to 409 dismissals that the company, based in Glenview, Ill., announced earlier this month. The nearly 800 workers will be let go from Zenith's Melrose Park plant, which analysts expect will eventually close or be sold. Zenith has reported only one profitable quarter since 1985.

Kites Fit for a Flea The first World's Smallest Kite competition was held in Seattle over the weekend, its goal to ''find the tiniest flyable kite on the planet.'' Hiko Yoshizumi of Kyoto, Japan, won with his 10-millimeter-by-8-millimeter sode kite, shown with a penny to provide perspective. Mr. Yoshizumi's kite will be submitted to the Guinness Book of World Records.

Less Violence Means Fewer Patients for Centers The number of trauma victims dropped 20 percent citywide between 1993 and 1996 -- good news for New Yorkers, but not necessarily so for the trauma centers that treat seriously injured victims.

Giuliani on Stadium Sites Mayor Giuliani said at a news conference that he would prefer that the Yankees remain in the Bronx, though he offered some justification for building the team a new stadium on the West Side of Manhattan.

Everything Old to Be New Again The last guests of the St. Moritz Hotel will check out today. The 1929 building will be stripped down to its steel girders, and be rebuilt in the style of a 1929 building that will contain condominiums.

Moynihan Seeking Funds Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York is to hold a major fund-raiser today, his first in nearly two years, making it appear that the 71-year-old Democrat is laying the groundwork for a campaign in 2000 for a fifth term.
Harlem Arson Investigation The police released a composite sketch of a man they said had twice threatened to firebomb a Harlem sporting goods store just days before the building was set ablaze.
2 Air Passengers Critical Two passengers of a Tower Air Boeing 747 that hit turbulence over the Atlantic on Saturday were in critical but stable condition.
Nets Win Playoff Berth The Nets clinched a berth in the N.B.A. playoffs by beating the Detroit Pistons, 114-101.
Yanks Finally Lose One The Detroit Tigers snapped the Yankees' eight-game winning by defeating New York, 2-1, in Detroit.

Work Visas Under Fire New immigration figures indicate that the information technology companies that apply for the most visas for high-skilled foreign workers use those workers for the kinds of jobs that critics say many Americans can easily be trained to perform.

Stocks Lower in Tokyo Stocks were trading lower in Tokyo today. At midday, the Nikkei index was down 46.71 points, or 0.30 percent, at 15,657.09. The Government announced that the trade surplus in March rose 56.5 percent from a year earlier.
Terry Sanford A Governor of North Carolina, a United States Senator and twice a Democratic candidate in the Presidential primaries, he was 80.
Linda Eastman McCartney The wife of Paul McCartney and a photographer whose portraits of 1960's rock stars have become classics, she was 56.
